definition: a recess in the wall of a church or a cupboard in the sacristy where sacred vessels, books, vestments, etc., are kept.
an often ornamented belt worn over one shoulder to support a sword or bugle
example: Baldrics have been used since ancient times, usually as part of military dress

definition: The fear of running out of reading material.
example: As a librarian, she always had multiple books on hand due to her abibliophobia.

definition: Indecision due to a lack of willpower.
example: His aboulomania prevented him from deciding where to go for dinner.

definition: Spiritual or mental sloth; apathy.
example: The monk was struggling with acedia and found it difficult to focus on his prayers.

definition: The belief that all things are inherently good.
example: Her agathism made her see the best in everyone.

definition: Someone who never laughs.
example: His serious demeanor and lack of humor earned him the nickname "agelast" among his friends.

definition: Full of twists and turns; winding.
example: The anfractuous path through the woods made it difficult to navigate.

definition: Situated on opposite sides of the earth; diametrically opposed.
example: The antipodal regions of the world have vastly different climates.

definition: A noisy or heated argument.
example: The argle-bargle between the politicians became a shouting match.

definition: A noisy and overexcited reaction or response to something.
example: The brouhaha over the celebrity's new haircut was unexpected.

definition: Having shapely buttocks.
example: The sculpture's callipygian figure was admired by all who saw it.

definition: A sudden and unaccountable change of mood or behavior.
example: His capriccio made him cancel his plans at the last minute.

definition: Feeling ill or indisposed due to excessive drinking or eating.
example: After the feast, everyone felt crapulent and regretted overindulging.

definition: Something or someone that attracts attention or admiration.
example: The new skyscraper became the cynosure of the city's skyline.

definition: The act of throwing someone or something out of a window.
example: The defenestration of the king's advisors led to a rebellion.

definition: An estate or property owned and managed by a wealthy landowner.
example: The sprawling demesne was the envy of all the neighboring lords.

definition: Sweet and soothing to the ear.
example: The dulcet tones of the musician's voice put the audience at ease.

definition: Relating to charity or giving alms.
example: The eleemosynary donations helped support the local homeless shelter.

definition: Payment or compensation received for work or services rendered.
example: The CEO's emolument was a hefty salary and stock options.

definition: To enchant or bewitch someone.
example: The witch's spell ensorcelled the unsuspecting victim.

definition: Relating to a sudden realization or comprehension.
example: The epiphanic moment helped her solve the puzzle she had been struggling with.

definition: Hungry or greedy.
example: The esurient raccoon raided the trash cans for food.

definition: Pleasing to the ear; harmonious.
example: The euphonic melody was easy to listen to and lifted the spirits.

definition: Fading away; disappearing.
example: The evanescent beauty of the sunset left a lasting impression.

definition: Distinguished; outstanding.
example: The eximious musician was renowned for her virtuosity.

definition: To speak or write at length on a subject.
example: The professor would expatiate on his area of expertise for hours.

definition: Producing or capable of producing many offspring; fertile.
example: The fecund couple had a large family of seven children.

definition: Relating to the trust between two parties, particularly in financial matters.
example: The accountant was a fiduciary for his clients' finances.

definition: The act of estimating something as worthless or trivial.
example: His floccinaucinihilipilification of the artwork offended the artist.

definition: To confuse or perplex someone.
example: The complex math problem flummoxed even the brightest students.

definition: Fleeting or transitory.
example: The fugacious moment passed quickly, leaving only a memory behind.

definition: To deny or dispute a fact or statement.
example: The witness's testimony was gainsaid by the defendant's lawyer.

definition: Calm and peaceful; prosperous.
example: The halcyon days of their childhood were filled with happiness and adventure.

definition: Mental lethargy or dullness.
example: The hebetude of the student's mind made it difficult for him to concentrate.

definition: The common people; the masses.
example: The celebrity shunned the hoi polloi and only socialized with other A-listers.

definition: Marked by disgrace or shame; humiliating.
example: The athlete's ignominious defeat was a crushing blow to his career.

definition: A confusing and complicated situation; a disagreement.
example: The political imbroglio caused a stalemate in the negotiations.

definition: Fearless or brave.
example: The impavid firefighter rushed into the burning building to save the trapped residents.

definition: Refusing to repent or show remorse for wrongdoing.
example: The impenitent criminal showed no regret for his actions.

definition: A spoken curse or malediction.
example: The angry driver shouted imprecations at the other driver who cut him off.

definition: Not fully formed or developed; in an early stage.
example: The idea for the novel was still inchoate and needed more work.

definition: Too great or extreme to be expressed or described in words.
example: The beauty of the sunset was ineffable and left him speechless.

definition: Unable to be avoided or escaped; inevitable.
example: The ineluctable truth of death made her appreciate life more.

definition: Harmful or hostile; unfriendly.
example: The inimical bacteria caused an infection in the patient's body.

definition: Carefree or unconcerned; nonchalant.
example: The insouciant attitude of the teenager annoyed his parents.

definition: Uncompromising or stubborn; refusing to change one's views or position.
example: The intransigent politician refused to negotiate on any of his policies.

definition: Having a particular habit, activity, or interest that is long-established and unlikely to change.
example: The inveterate gambler couldn't resist a game of poker, even though he knew he should quit.

definition: Showing luminous colors that seem to change when seen from different angles.
example: The iridescent wings of the butterfly shimmered in the sunlight.

definition: Humorous or playful; joking.
example: The jocose banter between the friends lightened the mood.

definition: A critical or decisive point in time or situation.
example: The juncture of the battle was a turning point in the war.

definition: A commotion or fuss, typically caused by a disagreement or misunderstanding.
example: The kerfuffle over the seating arrangements disrupted the dinner party.

definition: Tearful or inclined to weep.
example: The lachrymose child cried at the drop of a hat.

definition: Softly bright or radiant; glowing.
example: The lambent light of the candles cast a romantic glow on the room.

definition: Graceful or flexible; limber.
example: The ballerina's lissome movements captivated the audience.

definition: Tending to talk a lot or too much.
example: The loquacious professor's lectures were always interesting but tended to run long.

definition: A powerful whirlpool in the sea or a river; a chaotic or turbulent situation.
example: The maelstrom of emotions made it difficult for him to think clearly.

definition: Generous or forgiving; unselfish.
example: The magnanimous act of donating a large sum of money to charity impressed everyone.

definition: Wrongdoing or misconduct, especially by a public official.
example: The mayor was investigated for malfeasance and removed from office.

definition: Easily shaped or molded; adaptable.
example: The malleable clay could be formed into any shape.

definition: Sweetly or smoothly flowing; pleasant to hear.
example: The mellifluous sound of the violin filled the concert hall.

definition: Not telling the truth; lying.
example: The mendacious politician was caught in several lies during the debate.

definition: Attractive in a cheap, flashy way; insincere.
example: The meretricious decorations at the party looked tacky and artificial.

definition: A poisonous atmosphere or influence; a noxious odor.
example: The miasma emanating from the factory caused health problems for the nearby residents.

definition: Small or minor details, often tedious or insignificant.
example: The job required attention to minutiae, such as filing paperwork and answering emails.

definition: In a dying or declining state; near death.
example: The moribund company was struggling to stay afloat.

definition: Courage, determination, or energy; boldness.
example: The young entrepreneur had the moxie to start her own business and succeed.

definition: Extremely wicked or evil; criminal.
example: The nefarious scheme to defraud the elderly couple was exposed by the police.

definition: A beginner or novice; someone new to a field or activity.
example: The neophyte surfer struggled to catch his first wave.

definition: A connection or link; the central or most important point.
example: The nexus between the two events was unclear at first, but later became clear.

definition: Foul-smelling or offensive; harmful or dangerous.
example: The noisome smell of the decaying fish made the entire beach unpleasant to visit.

definition: Confused, surprised, or perplexed; at a loss for what to do or say.
example: The usually unflappable CEO was nonplussed when confronted with the unexpected question.

definition: Stubborn, unyielding, or resistant to persuasion.
example: The obdurate child refused to eat his vegetables despite his parents' insistence.

definition: To make something confusing or unclear; to obscure or cloud.
example: The politician tried to obfuscate his position on the issue, but his opponents saw through his attempts.

definition: Excessively eager to please or obey; fawning or servile.
example: The obsequious assistant was always trying to curry favor with the boss.

definition: Slow to understand or perceive; dull-witted or insensitive.
example: The obtuse student struggled to grasp the concepts presented in class.

definition: Hateful, repulsive, or offensive; deserving of strong dislike or disgust.
example: The odious smell of the garbage made it difficult to work in the kitchen.

definition: Excessively eager to offer unwanted help or advice; meddlesome or interfering.
example: The officious neighbor was always sticking her nose into other people's business.

definition: Burdensome, difficult, or oppressive; involving a heavy obligation or responsibility.
example: The onerous task of caring for her elderly parents was taking a toll on her health.

definition: Rich, luxurious, or lavish; characterized by wealth and abundance.
example: The opulent mansion was filled with expensive furniture and artwork.

definition: Apparent, but not necessarily true; supposed or alleged.
example: The ostensible reason for the war was to protect national security, but many believed it was for economic gain.

definition: To exclude or banish someone from a group or society; to shun or reject.
example: The bully tried to ostracize the new student, but the others stood up for him.

definition: A model of excellence or perfection; a person or thing that is perfect or outstanding.
example: The singer was considered a paragon of talent and charisma by her fans.

definition: Narrow-minded, provincial, or limited in outlook; focused on local or narrow concerns.
example: The parochial school had a strict curriculum and did not offer many extracurricular activities.

definition: A scarcity or shortage of something; an inadequate quantity.
example: The paucity of food and water made survival in the desert extremely difficult.

definition: A minor or petty offense; a small sin or fault.
example: Forgive me, Father, for I have committed many peccadillos in my life.

definition: Overly concerned with minor details or rules; excessively academic or formal.
example: The pedantic professor was more interested in showing off his knowledge than in engaging with his students.

definition: A strong liking or preference for something; a tendency or inclination.
example: The chef had a penchant for spicy foods and always added extra peppers to his dishes.

definition: Extreme poverty or destitution; a state of being without money or resources.
example: The family's penury forced them to rely on charity to survive.

definition: A long and meandering journey or trip; an extended period of travel.
example: The writer's peregrinations through Europe inspired many of her novels.

definition: Done without care or interest; superficial or hasty.
example: The salesperson's perfunctory greeting did not inspire confidence in the quality of his products.

definition: Having keen insight or understanding; mentally sharp or astute.
example: The perspicacious detective was able to solve the crime using only a few pieces of evidence.

definition: Calm and unemotional, even in difficult situations; stoic or impassive.
example: The phlegmatic doctor was able to remain focused and composed during the most stressful surgeries.

definition: A feeling of wounded pride or annoyance; to provoke or arouse.
example: The artist's pique at not being selected for the show was evident in his scathing review of the other artists' work.

definition: Concise and meaningful; terse or succinct.
example: The CEO's pithy speech inspired the employees to work harder and more efficiently.

definition: To calm or soothe someone who is upset or angry; to pacify or appease.
example: The manager tried to placate the irate customer by offering her a refund and an apology.

definition: A trite or overused remark; a banal or clich√©d statement.
example: The politician's speech was filled with platitudes and empty promises.

definition: A large or excessive amount of something; an abundance or profusion.
example: The bookstore had a plethora of books on every subject imaginable.

definition: Evoking a sense of sadness or regret; deeply moving or touching.
example: The writer's poignant memoir about his childhood in war-torn Syria brought tears to many readers' eyes.

definition: A powerful ruler or monarch; a person with great authority or influence.
example: The potentate of the kingdom had absolute control over all aspects of the government and society.

definition: Dealing with things in a practical and sensible way, rather than being guided by ideology or theory.
example: The pragmatic approach of the engineer was able to solve the problem of the bridge's collapsing.

definition: To speak or act in an evasive or ambiguous way; to lie or deceive.
example: The politician tried to prevaricate when asked about his involvement in the scandal, but the evidence was clear.

definition: A natural tendency or inclination toward something; a predisposition or preference.
example: The writer had a proclivity for dark and twisted stories that explored the darker side of human nature.

definition: Wasteful or reckless with money or resources; extravagant or lavish.
example: The prodigal heir to the family fortune spent his inheritance on cars, parties, and expensive vacations.

definition: Recklessly wasteful or immoral
example: The profligate spending habits of the government caused a major budget crisis that affected the entire country.

definition: Producing a large amount of something; highly productive or creative.
example: The prolific writer was able to publish several novels every year, each one more successful than the last.

definition: A natural tendency or inclination toward something; a proclivity or disposition.
example: The athlete had a propensity for taking risks, which sometimes led to spectacular feats but also to serious injuries.

definition: Lacking imagination or creativity; dull or ordinary.
example: The novelist's latest book was criticized for its prosaic writing style and predictable plot.

definition: Able to change or adapt easily; versatile or adaptable.
example: The actress was praised for her protean ability to transform herself into a wide range of characters on stage and screen.

definition: Physical beauty or attractiveness; the quality of being visually pleasing.
example: The beauty pageant contestant was known for her pulchritude, which earned her the crown.

definition: Complaining or whining in a petulant or whiny manner; irritable or fretful.
example: The querulous child constantly complained about every little thing, making it difficult for the parents to enjoy their vacation.

definition: Idealistic to the point of being unrealistic or impractical; overly romantic or visionary.
example: The entrepreneur's quixotic plan to revolutionize the industry by giving away all of his products for free was met with skepticism by investors.

definition: Bitterness or resentment, especially long-standing; deep-seated animosity or ill-will.
example: The rancor between the two rival gangs led to a violent turf war that lasted for years.

definition: Suggestive or reminiscent of something; evocative or reminiscent.
example: The old farmhouse was redolent of memories from the owner's childhood, bringing back a flood of emotions.

definition: Favorable to health or well-being; promoting good health or well-being.
example: The fresh mountain air and abundant sunshine made the resort town a salubrious place to live.

definition: Optimistic or positive, especially in a difficult or uncertain situation; hopeful or confident.
example: Despite the setbacks, the entrepreneur remained sanguine about the future of his business.

definition: Sparkling or shining brightly; brilliantly or impressively clever or skillful.
example: The scintillating fireworks display left the audience breathless and amazed.

definition: Spreading scandalous or malicious rumors or accusations; defamatory or slanderous.
example: The journalist's scurrilous article about the politician's personal life was widely criticized for its lack of journalistic ethics.

definition: The occurrence or development of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way; a fortunate coincidence.
example: Meeting her future husband at a coffee shop was just serendipity for the young woman.

definition: A job or position with little or no responsibility, especially one that provides a salary or income.
example: The CEO's son was given a sinecure position in the company, despite having no qualifications or experience.

definition: A nickname or descriptive name given to a person, especially one that has become well-known.
example: The actor was known by his sobriquet "The King of Cool" due to his suave and confident demeanor.

definition: The philosophical belief that only one's own mind is sure to exist or can be known to exist; extreme self-centeredness or selfishness.
example: The writer's solipsism was reflected in his works, which were often introspective and self-absorbed.

definition: Tending to induce drowsiness or sleep; sleepy or lethargic.
example: The soporific effect of the warm sun and gentle breeze made it difficult to stay awake on the beach.

definition: False or fake; not genuine or authentic.
example: The painting was discovered to be a spurious copy of a famous masterpiece, created to deceive buyers.

definition: Behaving or looking as though one thinks one is superior to others; arrogant or haughty.
example: The supercilious attitude of the wealthy socialite made her unpopular with many of her peers.

definition: Kept secret, especially because it would not be approved of; stealthy or clandestine.
example: The thief made a surreptitious entry into the museum, avoiding detection by the security guards.

definition: A person who acts obsequiously towards someone important in order to gain advantage; a flatterer or toady.
example: The sycophant was always hanging around the boss, hoping to curry favor and win promotions.

definition: Reserved or uncommunicative in speech; silent or reticent.
example: The taciturn old man rarely spoke, preferring to listen quietly to the conversations around him.

definition: The use of unnecessary or redundant words, often resulting in a repetitive or circular statement.
example: The politician's speech was filled with tautology and empty rhetoric, lacking any real substance or meaning.

definition: Excessive or foolish boldness; audacity or recklessness.
example: The young man had the temerity to challenge the authority of his boss in front of the entire office.

definition: Very weak or slight; insubstantial or fragile.
example: The argument for his innocence was based on tenuous evidence and could easily be disproven.

definition: Showing or suffering from a lack of confidence or courage; fearful or timid.
example: The timorous child clung to her mother's side, afraid to explore the unfamiliar surroundings.

definition: Vigorous or incisive in expression or style; sharp or cutting.
example: The writer's trenchant criticism of the government's policies was widely applauded for its clarity and insight.

definition: Eager or quick to argue or fight; aggressively defiant.
example: The truculent customer demanded a refund and became increasingly hostile when the store manager refused.

definition: Swollen or bloated; excessively ornate or complex in style or language.
example: The academic's turgid prose was nearly incomprehensible, filled with convoluted sentences and esoteric vocabulary.

definition: Present, appearing, or found everywhere; widespread or omnipresent.
example: The ubiquitous presence of smartphones has revolutionized the way we communicate and access information.

definition: Offense or annoyance caused by something that is perceived as insulting or disrespectful; resentment or displeasure.
example: The politician took umbrage at the reporter's question, accusing her of bias and unfairness.

definition: Excessively flattering or insincere; oily or greasy in texture or appearance.
example: The salesperson's unctuous demeanor was off-putting, making the customer feel like they were being manipulated or deceived.

definition: Excessively fond of or submissive to one's wife; henpecked.
example: The uxorious husband catered to his wife's every whim, constantly seeking her approval and affection.

definition: Having or showing a lack of intelligence or thought; mindless or empty.
example: The reality TV star's vacuous comments and behavior made her a target of ridicule and scorn.

definition: Offering nothing that is stimulating or challenging; dull or uninspiring.
example: The movie was a vapid and predictable romantic comedy, lacking any real depth or originality.

definition: Showing or motivated by a willingness to do anything for money; corrupt or mercenary.
example: The venal politician accepted bribes from wealthy donors in exchange for political favors and influence.

definition: A change of circumstances or fortune, typically one that is unwelcome or unpleasant; an unexpected change or variation.
example: The vicissitudes of the stock market can be difficult to predict, making investing a risky proposition.

definition: Filled with bitter criticism or malice; caustic or acrimonious.
example: The vitriolic attack on the actress's appearance by the tabloid was widely condemned as cruel and unnecessary.
